title: Records broken in historic Sydney Marathon wins
text:
Hailemaryam Kiros and Sifan Hassan have won the men's and women's races in the Sydney Marathon in record times.

Ethiopian runner Kiros was part of the lead pack and broke away late on, holding off a challenge from Addisu Gobena, with Tebello Ramakongoana from Lesotho finishing third.

He ran the race in 2:06:06, the fastest time in any marathon in Australia by over a minute.﻿

Kiros was confident of success, and he crossed the finish line in record time. (Getty Images for Adidas)

Kiros praised the overall competition at the end of the race: "[It was] very tough, these were strong, strong fields".

He said he always believed he would break the record, citing his strong preparation.﻿

World-class runner Eliud Kipchoge was considered the favourite to win the race in his first trip to Australia.

However, he fell behind the leading pack with around eight kilometres to go, and he finished in 11th place with a time of 2:08:31.﻿

Of the Australian runners, Haftu Strintzos was the fastest male, registering a time of 2:11:27 to finish 14th overall.

Sifan Hassan skipped the World Championships for the first time in 15 years to race in Sydney, and her decision paid off in record breaking fashion. (Getty Images for Adidas)

In the women's race, Dutch athlete Hassan also set a new record in her first-ever appearance at the Sydney Marathon.﻿

With a time of 2:18:20, she became the first woman in an Australian marathon to run it in less than two hours and 20 minutes.

Brigid Kosgei also broke that barrier as she finished in second place.﻿

"It's amazing, I'm really grateful, I'm so happy to win a course record," she said.

"It's history, it's the first major marathon and I'm the first winner."

She admitted she almost pushed too hard at the start of the race, saying it could have cost her on another day: "I [started] too hard and I learnt a lesson."﻿

READ MORE: Police move HQ in hunt for accused cop killer

The Sydney Marathon sees runners go past some of the most famous icons in the harbour city. (Getty)

Three Aussies finished in the top ﻿10 of the women's race, with Leanne Pompeani crossing the line with a time of 2:11:27, followed by Jessica Stenson with a time of 2:28:56, and Lisa Weightman finishing in 2:29:34.

An estimated 35,000 people are competing today, which is the first Sydney Marathon with world marathon major status, meaning it is one of the seven biggest marathons in the world.

The 42-kilometre course began in North Sydney and ends at the Sydney Opera House.﻿

Runners cross the Sydney Harbour Bridge this morning. (Edwina Pickles)

The event began at about 6.20am with the wheelchair race, whilst the elite runners started just after 6.30am.

To see the full results and to track the progress of every runner, check on the Sydney Marathon official website .

title: 'I'm just me. That's it, no trick': Peter Overton's 15 years on top
text:
P﻿eter Overton has dominated ratings in Sydney for 15 years and been a constant presence at Nine for 35 years.

Most know the ﻿59-year-old for delivering 9News Sydney's 6pm bulletin, or being the former reporter for 60 Minutes.

But to the people who know and love him, he is the same person on and off-air.

READ MORE: ﻿ Great weather divide across Australia taking hold

P﻿eter Overton has dominated screens for 35 years and ratings for 15 years. (9News)

"I've never changed. That's what my father says to me. He says 'You've never changed from being the young boy to the school student to the university student, to the young sports reporter to the great jobs in Australian commercial television'," he said.

The oldest of four siblings to parents who always kept them in line, Overton believes his upbringing and transparency are the ﻿reasons why he has resonated so much with the Australian audience.

"I'm just me," he said.

"That's it, no trick. It's just being true to who you are. ﻿I think it adds to the trust. ﻿

"The viewers are the smartest people in the house, and they can pick an imposter at 100 miles away."

From a young sports reporter in 1991 to a 60 Minutes reporter for almost a decade, Overton has now led 9News to claim the number one ratings in Sydney for the 15th consecutive year.

READ MORE: ﻿ Huge profit jump for Qantas powered by surging travel demand

Peter Overton has entered his 35th year in his career. (Cameron Williams/@camjwilliams)

It was a welcome accolade for the respected presenter as he ticked off another year in his career.

"I still pinch myself," he said.

"After 35 years, I reckon that's pretty darn cool to be able to say I love going to work every single day."

Overton fondly reflects on the stories he has shared throughout his career, which have taken him across the world and resonated across Australia.

From his coverage on the forgotten generation of cancer sufferers to mental health issues, he ﻿was able to see the real-life outcomes of his hard work.

"I was doing a story in Paris and Australians would come up to me in the airport or hotel and say thank you for doing that story," he said.

"And that meant a lot to me."

READ MORE: ﻿ Uber rolls out rideshare for teens across Australia

Peter Overton reporting for 60 Minutes in New York City. (Nine)

Co-hosting Queen Elizabeth's funeral with Tracy Grimshaw would remain one of his biggest stories.

"We were on air for 12 or 13 hours non-stop ad libbing," he recalled.

"We had massive technical challenges, and we couldn't see anything or hear anything, and we still had to keep pedalling hard, but we did it, and I think Trace and I were both really proud of that."﻿

Overton still begins each day ﻿listening to the radio, driven by the adrenaline and challenges that come with the job.

"﻿You're not always going to get it right in those environments," he admitted.

"But you give it your best, you do it authentically, and you do it as a team."

Peter Overton at the 65th Logies Awards on August 3. (Getty Images for TV WEEK Logies)

Despite his recent scare with melanoma and a polyp, Overton said he is not ready to part with the job he loves or the success so soon.

"I've got a few more years left," he said.

"Fifteen years as the dominant number one in the Sydney market is a real tribute to the people I work alongside, and we don't take anything for granted.

"I treat every night as opening night. That's what we do, all of us, and it's paying a lovely dividend for us all." ﻿

When Overton finally goes home for the day, he said he is "just dad" to his two girls. ﻿

"It's really nice. They're not blindsided or impressed," he said. ﻿

title: 'I've always thrived on variety': Ben Lee on finding balance in life
text:
As a touring musician, producer, DJ, podcaster, father and husband, Ben Lee is no stranger to multitasking.

Since entering the public consciousness at 14 with his band Noise Addict, he has released 15 solo albums, acted alongside Rose Byrne and undertaken numerous explorations into alternative spirituality.

He now hosts the podcast Weirder Together with his wife, actor and author Ione Skye and is about to embark on a national tour to mark the 20th anniversary of his double platinum album Awake is the New Sleep.

After spending much of the past three decades in the United States, last year he moved back to Australia with Skye, their teenage daughter, Goldie, and stepdaughter Kate.

Ben Lee and his wife, actor and author Ione Skye, host the podcast Weirder Together. (Supplied: Ben Lee)

"I feel like, as artists, we have to somewhat go with the flow of life, where the work is, where the energy is, and it does feel like an amazing time to be in Sydney, creatively," Lee says.

They live on the traditional lands of the Gadigal and Birrabirragal people with their dog, Gus. Ben shares how he finds balance in a busy life.

Unwind with … is a column that explores the simple ways interesting people take care of themselves.

A typical day for me involves…

I get up early. I have a teenager, so I pack her some lunch and get her off to school. I'm enjoying exercising, I feel like late 40s is the right time, so I'm working out, doing Pilates.

I've always really thrived on variety, so I always have a lot of different projects and different collaborations and different things happening. At the moment, it's quite chill because I've got this bigger tour later in the year, so I deliberately took a bit of time off the road.

We do a lot of social things in the evenings and part of what's been fun about the podcast growing is we get invited to so many great things, and now it's nice because our kids are older, [so] we can do that.

Ben Lee with Grammy winning English musician Jacob Collier after a recent event in Sydney. (Supplied: Ben Lee)

For me, a break looks like…

How Dominic Field unwinds Photo shows Dominic Field is dressed in a green wig and a green theatrical outfit, and is posing for the camera as the Tree of Wisdom. Dominic Field' latest role in the Wiggles, as the Tree of Wisdom, has taken his career to new heights. He shares how he finds time to relax and enjoy his downtime.

As a freelance artist, I have somewhat of a resistance to holidays … because you feel like either you don't deserve them, or [think], 'Is work going to come up?'

I always look at people that have "normal" jobs and just the way they know what their year's going to be like seems so crazy for me.

But me and Ione are going to go to Bangkok the week after next for me to get some suits made for the tour.

That's kind of my favourite type of holiday, where you make it like a work holiday, sort of, and tie in some fun.

To find balance during busy periods…

I talk to my wife. I love just having some time to just break it down, like, go for a walk and a talk and every now and then.

Sign up to the ABC Lifestyle newsletter Get a mid-week boost and receive easy recipes, wellbeing ideas, and home and garden tips in your inbox every Wednesday. You’ll also receive a monthly newsletter of our best recipes.

It'll maybe have been a stressful day, or there's parenting things going on and we're like, 'Do you want to go get a martini at Paradise?', which is a little wine bar we like up in Potts Point. We'll go for 45 minutes and just talk and go, 'Oh my God, we've got to remember to do this, this is so grounding'.

It just brings it back to two people who want to help each other get through. It's really nice.

My favourite place to unwind…

A secluded Central Coast beach is one of Ben Lee's favourite places to relax. (Google Maps)

Anytime I'm touring up and down the [NSW] Central Coast and have the chance to step onto a beach that's got no-one on it.

You might have driven for four or five hours and suddenly you're just like walking out onto this beautiful piece of coastline that's just empty.

That's one of my favourite experiences.

Changes I have made or tasks I have stopped doing…

I micromanage things that I'm involved in quite a lot and I'm starting to realise … your time is limited and there are things you can delegate.

Realising time is limited and it is OK to delegate tasks for others has been a game-changer for Ben Lee. (Supplied: Ben Lee)

So, in general, I'm more open to delegation of admin than I've ever been and I'm more of a believer in that having more time to be creative is worth respecting.

A piece of advice I often turn to…

I suppose the most fundamental thing spiritual exploration has given me is a firm belief that the life that happens to you is where you'll learn the lessons you need to learn.

Stream now on ABC iview Photo shows 5 women looking concerned in front of a beach with Family Next Door and iview logo. The enigmatic Isabelle arrives in the quiet seaside cul-de-sac of Pleasant Court — and suspicions quickly rise. Stream all episodes now on ABC iview.

It's not from some esoteric book that only a few people have access to, or that's hidden in a church, in a vault, or anything like that.

I'm not saying everything happens for a reason, but you can have that attitude and that belief and learn from everything, and everything is useful in a way.

I guess that's the main thing, not living like a victim of circumstance.

title: Prepaid electricity customers struggle to keep the power on
text:
When darkness falls over Alice Springs and the temperature plummets towards freezing, grandmother Alfreda Dunn and the people she lives with turn on heaters and hope the electricity lasts the night.

All too often, it doesn't.

Ms Dunn and six others, including her grandson, share public housing and rely on prepaid electricity via Central Australia's only provider, Jacana Energy, a Northern Territory government-owned corporation.

In a brisk desert winter, electricity costs the household about $560 a month, an outlay that leaves little for other essentials, including weekly food shopping.

Vulnerable powerless as prepaid electricity cards run out Photo shows A shadowy image of an Aboriginal man and child riding through the outback in the backseat of a car. As outback temperatures soar, vulnerable tenants with prepaid power are regularly seeing their electricity cut.

"I have about $60, $65 [left]," Ms Dunn said.

She said heaters, plus basic appliances — a fridge, kettle, phone chargers and hot water system — devoured electricity at an alarming rate.

"Our power goes off and we feel cold in the night and we get hungry," she said.

Ms Dunn said the power went off frequently, leaving her to try to find someone in the family to help with the cost and have it restored.

"Sometimes it takes one day or two days but [after] one hour it goes off because we're using too many [appliances]," she said.

Calls for Jacana tariffs reform

The plight of Ms Dunn and others like her has led Jonathon Pilbrow, an Alice Springs-based social policy consultant, to call on the NT government to immediately reduce prepaid electricity tariffs.

"It's really cold," he said.

"It's 1 degree overnight at the moment. People need heaters on.

" I feel like people in prepayment meter households are being treated like second-class citizens. "

He says the prepaid tariff is 33 cents per kilowatt hour, compared with the cheaper rate and daily fixed charge (about 50 cents) of post-payment accounts.

"Once they hit 20 kilowatt hours per day, they start paying more, in effect," he said.

Jonathon Pilbrow says prepaid electricity customers should pay the same tariffs as other customers. (ABC Alice Springs: Emma Haskin)

Mr Pilbrow said prepaid customers had fewer consumer protections and no customer service, unlike the "limited hardship protections or provisions that post-paid customers get".

He said all Jacana customers should pay the same tariff.

"If the Northern Territory government is interested in bringing down disconnection rates from 80,000 per year, reducing tariffs is one way," he said.

"I think we can do better as a territory to make electricity more accessible and more affordable."

Neediest 'missing out' on concessions

Those on disability pension or an aged pension qualify for a Northern Territory concession card.

"That gives them up to $1,200 per year in a concession for electricity," Mr Pilbrow said.

"However, if you receive the Jobseeker payment or youth allowance, you're not eligible for that concession."

That meant people on the lowest incomes in the Northern Territory were not eligible for cheaper electricity.

"That would make an enormous difference to households if they were able to receive that additional $1,200 per year," he said.

"We have a complete injustice in the system and those who need the concession the most are missing out."

The Northern Territory government has been contacted for comment.

title: Gold Coast gun to face side that drafted him a decade ago in historic final
text:
When Lachie Weller runs out onto Perth Stadium, he'll be part of a history-making Gold Coast side — the first in the club's history to play in an AFL final.

But for Weller it carries extra significance, as he will be playing the side that drafted him back in 2014, and he's overcome serious hurdles just to still be running around in the league.

In 2022, he ruptured the ACL in his right knee, and underwent a reconstruction, which kept him out of the game for 10 months.

Then just nine games into his return from injury in 2023, he suffered another rupture, and had a second reconstruction.

Lachie Weller missed 10 months with his first knee injury, before suffering another one in 2023. (AAP Image/Jono Searle)

"It is such a long injury to be out with, I didn't know if I could get back and play," Weller said.

"Even to the point where I didn't know if I wanted to get back and play.

"It was a pretty challenging couple of years, but I'm super pumped to have stuck it out and really proud of myself to be back out there."

Weller only played 15 games across the 2023 and 2024 seasons, but has managed that figure this year alone.

Long wait finally over

Weller debuted for the Dockers in 2015, after being selected with pick 13 the previous year, but he wasn't selected for the side's finals campaign.

Weller has played 15 games in 2025, the same number he managed in 2023 and 2024 combined

He then played every game in 2016 and 2017 before being traded to Gold Coast in exchange for pick two, in a move widely criticised as being too high a cost for the Suns.

110 games later, and he's about to play finals for the first time in his 10-year career.

"When I first came over here I obviously wanted to play finals for the Suns and it's taken a long time," Weller said.

"There's been a lot of guys who have been at the club for a long time that have wanted this.

" We've dreamt of this for so long. "

Farewelling Fyfe

For the Suns to keep their dreams of a maiden Premiership alive, they will have to end the dreams of one of the game's greats.

Weller played with Fremantle great Nat Fyfe for three years, and will now play against him in his final game in Perth. (AAP Image/Joe Castro)

Fremantle midfielder Nat Fyfe will be playing his final game in Perth, and if they lose, his final AFL game.

"I loved Fyfey when I was at the club, and I've still kept in touch with him," Weller said.

"He's a great player and he's had a great career, so it's pretty special I get to play his last game maybe, and definitely his last game in Perth.

"It's pretty special to celebrate his career, but hopefully we spoil it."

The original Sun

The end of Fyfe's career coincides with the potential end of the original Gold Coast Sun.

David Swallow is the last remaining inaugural Sun, and has played a record 247 games without ever featuring in a final. (AAP Image/Dave Hunt)

David Swallow was the club's first ever selection, taken with pick one in 2010, and has played 247 games, but never in a final.

It's the AFL's longest streak, which could be ended if he's picked by Damian Hardwick for Saturday night's game.

"He's given everything to this football club," Weller said of the veteran.

"If you speak to Dave, he's just happy to be part of it, if he plays or not.

"But to run out with him would be pretty special."
