title: Reading retreats offer women time to devour a good book in nature
text:
The trope of the tired modern woman exhausted by the relentless family-work-life juggle is oft-cited.

But more and more women, regardless of whether they are mothers or not, are calling a timeout on the pressures of life and are heading to women-only reading retreats.

Established as weekend getaways in regional towns, all meals and activities are taken care of, allowing guests to simply kick back and read.

Often held at the beach or in picturesque locations, these retreats are designed to be dreamy and idyllic, and help an increasing number of women reporting symptoms of burnout.

Timeout

Anneli McKinnon's life is centred on books.

She is a member of two book clubs on Gippsland's Bass Coast, works at a local library, and hosts a monthly book dinner where guests can discuss their favourite titles over a meal.

Her latest venture is a women's spring reading retreat on the Walkerville coastline near Wilsons Promontory.

It is aimed at uniting women in a neutral space where they can read, relax and be completely taken care of all weekend.

"I always think it would be so nice to have a whole day just to read a book and we all know that does not happen at home," she said.

Reading retreat host Anneli McKinnon says literature is a wonderful unifier. (ABC Gippsland: Madeleine Stuchbery)

Ms McKinnon said women often got distracted at home, or felt guilty for taking time to sit and relax.

She said by heading away on a reading retreat, participants could unburden themselves of expectations or work, and could invest time in themselves.

Being in a bush environment is also a key part of the retreat, providing space for women to connect with nature, with other women, and with themselves.

"There's something about reading and talking about books that takes you to deeper levels quicker," Ms McKinnon said.

"You enter through a book, rather than if you just started with chit chat.

"Reading fiction is a great thing for your brain, for creating and fostering empathy, that's been proven."

A regular women-only book retreat is held at Walkerville South in Victoria. (ABC News: Kathy Lord)

Burning out

The Women's Ambition Report, published by Women's Agenda, found 72 per cent of the 2,000 women surveyed in 2025 experienced burnout — a form of emotional exhaustion — in the past 12 months.

The burnt-out millennials who walked away from work Photo shows Illustration of woman standing under umbrella with lots of writing bouncing off the outside umbrella. With burnout at unprecedented levels who doesn't dream of stepping away from it all and embracing a career break. But can it solve the problem?

Symptoms can include low energy, motivation or mood; feeling isolated or trapped; disengagement from work; procrastination; decreased life satisfaction; disrupted sleep; and physical symptoms such as headaches and body pain.

Women's Agenda co-founder Angela Priestley said 61 per cent of the women who reported symptoms of burnout thought it stemmed from balancing home life and a career.

"The key thing that comes up over and over again, and we've done this for 10 years now, is the leading ambition for women — around 30-35 per cent — is to earn more," Ms Priestley said.

"I think we need to look at the societal structures that are creating the pressure.

"You can go on a retreat, you might go to a spa for a day or something, and that can be good … but that's not going to change the underlying reason behind what may have led to burnout."

A place to pause

Crystal Wells runs a series of reading retreats for women across regional Victoria, including in the noted book town, Clunes.

She said while a weekend off may not be the silver bullet to resolve broader societal pressures, carving out time for oneself could be a good tool to mitigate stress.

Women are seeking respite from their busy modern lives at reading retreats across Australia. (Supplied: Crystal Wells)

"This myth of the superwoman, who pursues this high-powered career and is a perfect mum, and devotes her supposed downtime to self-improvement and all these things … a light has shone on that being a bit of a myth," she said.

"Maybe more people are feeling more comfortable to discuss the fact this isn't something that's achievable, that pushing ourselves to the nth degree in every aspect of our lives is not actually going to result in a high quality of life for us, as women."

title: Sinner says he's 'not a machine' after dropping a set against Shapovalov
text:
Jannik Sinner has been broken for the first time in week one of the US Open. Dropped the opening set, even. Fell way behind in the third set, too.

"I'm not a machine, you know," he said with the hint of a smile on Saturday.

"I also struggle, sometimes."

Sure, Jannik, maybe so.

Still, Sinner is the top-ranked player in men's tennis and has won the past three grand slam tournaments played on hard courts, so no-one was surprised when he set aside some lapses and emerged to beat number 27 Denis Shapovalov 5-7, 6-4, 6-3, 6-3 on Saturday to take his title defence at Flushing Meadows to the fourth round.

"That I have pressure and tension is normal. I've had that for a year, and you need to handle it," the Italian said.

"Either you handle it — or you don't. … It's better to have to deal with that than not."

On Monday, Sinner will face number 14 Tommy Paul of the United States or number 23 Alexander Bublik of Kazakhstan for a place in the quarterfinals.

Sinner's latest triumph stretched his hard court unbeaten run at majors to 24 matches, covering championships at the US Open in 2024 and the Australian Open in 2024 and 2025. He also won the trophy at Wimbledon on grass courts in July.

But Sinner's set streak in New York ended; he had claimed 14 in a row since dropping one in a victory against 2021 champion Daniil Medvedev in the quarterfinals a year ago.

Sinner explained that his serve did not feel quite right on Saturday, and that Shapovalov was reading it well.

"I was able to put pressure on Jannik today, so who says that another player can't do the same?" Shapovalov said.

Sinner double-faulted to close the opening set, which earlier featured a remarkable 30-stroke point in which both men hit drop shots. Sinner took that point by sprinting back to the baseline and twisting his body to deliver a lob winner that floated just out of Shapovalov's reach.

After rebounding to even the match at a set apiece, Sinner found himself trailing 3-0, love-30 in the third after Shapovalov grabbed 14 of 17 points.

ABC Sport Daily podcast ABC Sport Daily is your daily sports conversation. We dive into the biggest story of the day and get you up to speed with everything else that's making headlines.

"Key moment," Sinner would say later.

From there, he took nine games in a row to seize control.

"We were going toe to toe. It was a very close match. A lot of games were very close," said Shapovalov, a left-hander from Canada who was a Wimbledon semifinalist in 2021.

"He's number one for a reason. He dealt with it really well. He fights extremely well. He did a tremendous job to turn it around down 3-0 in the third there."

AP

title: A gambling spiral all but broke Mic. His grandfather's war diary was his path out
text:
Mic Whitty is cycle touring around Australia, stopping at war graves along the way.

With his yellow postal bike laden with gear, including a hammock that he strings between trees each night, Mic can choose to wake up to ocean views, glorious sunrises or rolling green hills.

It looks like an idyllic lifestyle — a permanent vacation, even.

His friendly disposition and contagious gratitude give the impression that Sydney-born Mic doesn't have a care in the world.

Warning: This article discusses gambling addiction, depression and suicidal ideation

Mic Whitty lives the simple life as he bike-packs around the world. (Supplied: Mic Whitty)

The reality is that Mic has been living rough for 11 years following a chain of events that left him broke and sleeping in the Welsh wilderness.

As a weapons technician in Saudi Arabia, and later as an IT consultant, Mic had a good income and a comfortable lifestyle.

When accepting a new job led to imposter syndrome and a mental health crisis in his early 40s, Mic moved to the United Kingdom, where he began working in a youth hostel.

"I was very happy, but I was on minimum wage," he said.

"I still had a champagne taste from my years in Saudi Arabia.

"But I was on a beer budget, so I was burning through my resources."

Mic had a career with the RAAF and then a lucrative job in Saudi Arabia. (Supplied: Mic Whitty)

Gambling creeps in

With his savings quickly depleting, along with an inheritance from his parents, Mic turned to gambling in an attempt to maintain his lifestyle.

"That was the beginning of my downfall," he said.

Mic had never gambled before but began betting on stock market predictions.

A win on his first day set him on a costly one-way path that changed the trajectory of his life forever.

"It seemed like a simpler way of 'investing' in the stock market, without having to buy and sell shares through a broker," Mic said.

Over six years, Mic lost all of his savings and the inheritance his parents left him. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jennifer Nichols)

Very quickly, Mic began losing significant amounts of money.

Trapped by the gambler's fallacy, he was driven to "win it back" but was unable to recover his mounting losses.

With his savings gone, and an eye-watering 18 months of rent unpaid, Mic felt increasingly alone, desperate and ashamed.

"It's just a spiral down," he said.

He anxiously waited for a call from his landlord, a friend, to query the missing rent.

"As I've done many times before in my life when it comes to finances, I guess I just put my head in the sand," he said.

When that call finally came, it was a moment of truth for Mic, and he chose honesty.

"If I've learned anything from studying politics and history, it's like Nixon and Clinton," he said.

"It's not the original sin that they got in trouble for. It's the cover after the lie."

From bad to worse

Determined to repay his debt, Mic moved into the youth hostel where he worked, and with the support of his old landlord, came up with a payment plan.

Still believing he could "claw back" his savings, Mic continued to gamble using the small amount of money he had left each month.

"I had gone through all my money, my parents' inheritance money," he said.

"That's where it really started unravelling."

Stream Mic Whitty's way out of the woods Photo shows Richard Fidler and Sarah Kanowski in front of a colorful background with the words "Conversations 20th Anniversary Collection" After walking away from his life, Mic re-entered the world again and came up with an extraordinary project.

Over several months, Mic took money from his work to gamble and concealed it by "fiddling the books".

"It spiralled out to where I'd taken out about 1,600 GBP ($3,300). And I had nothing to put back in," he said.

It came to a head when his manager noticed what was happening and wracked with shame, Mic tearfully owned up to stealing the money.

He resigned and borrowed money from a friend to repay what he had taken.

Almost daily, Mic struggled with thoughts of taking his own life to end the intense shame he felt.

"I don't blame any of this on depression … I got depressed because of what I did," he said.

"I was in a pretty bad way."

Retreating from the world

Despite struggling with daily life, Mic found another job and remained determined to repay his friend.

"I was just, every day, dragging myself out of bed to go to work. And when I wasn't working, I was just staying in bed," he said.

As soon as Mic made the last repayment to his mate, he skipped his work shift and walked out of his "old life" without telling anyone.

Discarding his phone, unlocked in his room — with a message for his friends to find — Mic then left all of his belongings and caught a train to the end of the line.

When he arrived in the small old mining town of Blaenau Ffestiniog in North West Wales, Mic walked off into the surrounding countryside.

With no tent or bedding, he found a secluded spot about 3 kilometres from town, and stayed there.

"As I think back on it now, it just sounds so irrational. But at the time I thought it was rational," Mic said.

"I went for a week without food, and I went probably two or three days before I crawled down to a creek just to drink some water.

" The only way I could see getting through the misery of it all is that I, in my mind, knew that the end was nigh. "

After a week in the woodland, Mic wandered into town to buy some food, but continued living rough, moving every couple of days to remain unnoticed.

Without basic comforts or entertainment, and with a makeshift bed fashioned from cardboard, Mic found sleep near impossible.

Boredom and rumination quickly crept in.

"I wasn't sleeping at all really … it's a very long time with nothing to do," Mic said.

"And the nights are probably worse than the days. You're just lying there, not really sure how long you can keep on going."

Finding his way back

For about three months, Mic hid away from his old life, too ashamed to reach out to friends.

After enduring the uncertainty, isolation and monotony of living rough, things took a turn for Mic when he caught a bus to Aberystwyth, a small Welsh seaside town.

He spent a week feeling invisible until Mic noticed a Salvation Army church hall and the familiar logo of the Red Shield Appeal.

Desperate for a cup of tea after months without, he gingerly walked over, hoping he could find some hospitality.

A simple sign that read, "Tea and coffee. All welcome" led Mic through the doors of that hall where he befriended another man sleeping rough who took Mic under his wing and they enjoyed a hot lunch.

Now cycling around Australia, Mic can make his own cuppa with his camp stove. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jennifer Nichols)

Over the weeks to come, Mic made more friends at the Salvation Army, including the town's librarian, Catherine Taylor, who encouraged Mic to visit the library each day.

This gave him routine, a warm sanctuary and access to newspapers and books to occupy his mind again.

"Whenever the library was open, at nine in the morning till six at night, I was sitting in the library — six days a week," he said.

Catherine's kindness extended to buying and sharing meals with Mic.

"I even ended up begging a couple of times on the streets, and she would be walking by with her family and this would upset her a great deal," he said.

"So she would drag me into a cafe and buy me something to eat and a coffee with her family … then she invited me to her home for a Sunday meal."

It was a gesture that Mic decided to honour with transparency about his past.

"As soon as I crossed the threshold, I said, 'I've got something to tell you … I stole money from work, and that's why I'm homeless,'" he said.

Librarian Catherine Taylor befriended Mic, welcoming him into her home and the town's library for refuge. (Supplied: Maude Wells)

To Mic's surprise, Catherine replied with her own confession that she had Googled him, but in doing so, had discovered a Facebook page dedicated to finding him.

This revelation helped Mic realise that there could be a way out of his situation, and that many people cared about him.

It took some time to process, but finally, almost 10 months after first walking away from his life, Mic felt strong enough to re-emerge.

He posted a Facebook message letting his friends know where he was, that he was safe, and what had happened.

"The reaction to that, it still, nine years on, brings me to tears," Mic said.

" I had so many positive replies and so many expressions of love. "

A new purpose

During Mic's process of reconnecting with his friends and his old life, he began pulling together his belongings that were stored in various friends' homes.

While searching through a tea chest full of sentimental treasures, Mic found his grandfather's World War I pocket diary, which had taken a bullet for his grandfather while he was serving in the Australian artillery on the Western Front.

After reconnecting with his life, Mic found his paternal grandfather's 1916 war diary, which bears the mark of a bullet. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jennifer Nichols)

With the diary in his hands, Mic was struck with the idea to honour his grandfather by riding his bike to Gallipoli, sleeping in a hammock along the way.

Once he arrived, Mic learnt that there are many war cemeteries at Gallipoli and he felt compelled to visit them all.

"I'd only really known of the ones we learned of in school; Lone Pine, The Neck, Anzac Cove," he said.

"It took me a couple of weeks, but I ended up cycling on my bike to all [the] cemeteries that are on the Gallipoli Peninsula.

"I was quite chuffed for myself. I noticed that … in a lot of them, it had been over a year since the previous person had signed in the visitors' book."

Mic reached the Lone Pine Cemetery on the Gallipoli Peninsula in March 2016. (Supplied: Mic Whitty)

Discovering how much he enjoyed cycle touring, and realising he had "nothing else better to do", Mic set himself a new and monumental goal.

"A bit like Forrest Gump, I'm now on a 30-year trip to cycle to every Commonwealth War Grave cemetery in the world," he said.

Mic Whitty is riding his way up the Queensland coast, hoping to arrive in Cooktown for Christmas. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jennifer Nichols)

Mic's itinerary takes in both purpose-built war cemeteries like the ones he visited in Gallipoli, as well as small-town 'regular' cemeteries where WWI or WWII casualties are buried.

If he sticks to his schedule, before the end of the centenary of World War II in 2045, Mic will have visited nearly 25,000 cemeteries.

"If I haven't finished by the time I'm 80, I'll just keep going," he said.

"If I happen to die beforehand, that solves the problem of 'What the heck do I do until I die?'"

Mic, pictured at Gympie Cemetery, has been cycling around the world visiting war graves and has no plans to stop. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jennnifer Nichols)

On reflection

Almost 10 years since he started, Mick has no regrets and favours taking his trip one day at a time.

"I haven't looked back," he said.

"I absolutely love it. I would not swap this for anything else.

"It's not about the cemeteries — it's the people I meet along the way."

While still technically a rough sleeper, Mic is living his best life on the road, wild camping by choice. (ABC Sunshine Coast: Jennifer Nichols)

Mic told his story to Richard Fidler on Conversations in March last year, and has cycled a total of 67,022 kilometres, visiting more than 4,000 war grave cemeteries.

This year, he's been tracking his way up the east coast of Australia.

"I am aiming for Cooktown by Christmas, so if anyone spots me along the Queensland coast, please toot your horn," he said.

After touring the war graves across almost 20 countries, Mic is now making his way around Australia. (Mic Whitty/ABC Sunshine Coast: Jennifer Nichols)

As he reflects on those dark, isolated months sleeping rough in Wales, Mic said it showed him an inner strength that he didn't realise he had.

"We're all a lot tougher than we think we would be when tested," he said.

As for that generous cup of tea Mic was offered by the Salvation Army, he still recalls it as "fantastic".

"You know how some people leave a bit of tea at the bottom of every cup? To this day, I drink all my tea," he said.

"And every time, I think just how lucky I am."

Stream the 20th Anniversary Collection of Conversations throughout August on the ABC listen app.

title: Wallaroos still alive after World Cup draw with United States
text:
Australia's Wallaroos have battled to eke out a 31-31 draw against the USA in the most thrilling match yet at the Women's Rugby World Cup, with both sides still able to reach the quarterfinals.

In a thrilling contest in which both sides scored five tries on Saturday, brilliant doubles for Australian back-line stars Desiree Miller and teenager Caitlyn Halse at York Community Stadium were countered by a superb hat-trick from American flanker Freda Tafuna.

With the match in the balance, replacement prop Eva Karpani ploughed over for the Aussies' fifth try with five minutes left to level the scores, but half-back Sam Wood missed the conversion attempt that could have sealed the victory to guarantee a place in the last eight.

"On the whole, a bit disappointed, a bit flat," sighed the Wallaroos' English coach Jo Yapp, when asked how she felt.

"We let them into the game in that second half and our penalty-count (Australia 13 USA 6) allowed them access to our half, and when they're in there, they're hard to stop. Ultimately our discipline really let us down."

"We'll always reflect and look to bounce back — the girls have got a big game next week."

Though the game had been billed as win-or-bust, the draw still allows both sides to dream, with everything now hanging on the final group A matches next week, with Australia facing the hot favourites and hosts England while the US plays Samoa.

Australia currently looks to be just about in the driving seat, as it has a mighty 135-points-difference advantage over the US, but if it cops a massive hiding from England and the Americans steamroll the exhausted Samoans, it is possible that could be overturned.

But the Australians' fate is in their own hands, if they can grab a bonus point against the English in Brighton.

England earlier continued its magisterial progress, hammering Samoa 92-3 in Northampton after beating the US 69-7 in the opening match.

It was another performance designed to worry the Wallaroos that they could still be in trouble.

"The feeling's a bit mixed," co-captain Kaitlan Leaney said.

"We were on top in parts and they came back. We feel flat. It feels like a loss."

AAP

title: Tourists shun the sun for a cool Tassie experience
text:
For Joanne and Justin, the Tasmanian winter has been a welcome relief from the heat of their home country, Singapore.

"Tasmania during the wintertime is like perfect, you get the best of both worlds," Joanne said.

Joanne and Justin have enjoyed a winter holiday in Tasmania. (ABC News: Sophie Jaggers)

The couple and their family completed a road trip of the southernmost state in August.

" It's relaxing enough that we can bring a whole family of eight here. "

The family is part of a growing cohort of tourists coming to Tasmania to experience the winter season.

Snow is one of the attractions offered by Tasmania in winter. (ABC News: Luke Bowden)

Tourism Tasmania CEO Sarah Kingston Clark said visitor numbers during April, May and June were up by three per cent compared to the same period last year.

"It was actually our best June quarter that we've ever seen from a visitor perspective," Ms Kingston Clark said.

She said a big part of this boom was thanks to the return of Dark Mofo, which sold 103,000 tickets and generated $4.6 million at the box office.

Thousands of people participated in the Dark Mofo nude solstice swim. (ABC News: Ebony ten Broeke)

Dark Mofo artistic director Chris Twite said after scaling back the festival in 2024, he was glad to see the large crowds enjoying the winter festival.

"Winter in Tasmania is a completely different experience from winter elsewhere in the country and people really revel in that opportunity," Mr Twite said.

The Winter Feast at Dark Mofo. (Supplied: Dark Mofo/Jesse Hunniford)

"[The festival] is so intrinsically linked to the solstice and to that time of year in Hobart, and the space of Hobart allows us to do a festival that is very different from any kind of festival in Australia."

Ms Kingston Clark said another element to the off-season’s success was the growing recognition of the unique winter experience that Tasmania can provide.

Curringa Farm owner Tim Parsons. (ABC News: Sophie Jaggers)

Stream now on ABC iview Photo shows 5 women looking concerned in front of a beach with Family Next Door and iview logo. The enigmatic Isabelle arrives in the quiet seaside cul-de-sac of Pleasant Court — and suspicions quickly rise. Stream all episodes now on ABC iview.

Tim Parsons owns Curringa Farm, a sheep farm in central Tasmania which offers farm tours and on-site accommodation.

Bookings have remained steady during the winter, he said.

"It's so much easier to back up to a fire and have a hot drink or a glass of whiskey and get warm and rug up with a coat and have good conversation.

"The pace is slower, the expectation of a bit of snow, the appetite to catch an aurora is a driver."

An aurora visible at Ben Lomond in northern Tasmania. (Supplied: Nathan Waterhouse)

Ms Kingston Clark said there had been an increase in visitors wanting to "meet the maker" and experience agricultural life first-hand.

"Fifty per cent of people who come to Tasmania will actually engage with an agritourism experience while they're here, so we are definitely becoming more well known for those sorts of experiences," she said.

International markets bounce back

Mr Parsons said 80 per cent of Curringa Farm visitors were from overseas, primarily Singapore and Hong Kong.

International visitors in particular are contributing to the rise in tourist numbers. (ABC News: Sophie Jaggers)

Tourism Tasmania noted an increase from international markets over the winter, too.

"The US, the UK and Singapore have been performing really well for us in Tasmania and we're also seeing emerging markets, like India," Ms Kingston Clark said.

" People are really interested in those four seasons; they don't just want to follow the sun. "

Mr Parsons said a successful winter season indicated a good summer to come.

"Our business through winter has been really encouraging.

"We know summer is going to be better this year than last year, and last year was an upshot on the year before."

title: 'Homophobia permeates every square centimetre' of the AFL
text:
This week, former West Coast Eagles defender Mitch Brown came out as the first current or former openly bisexual male player in the AFL's nearly 130-year history.

He said there were times in his life and career in the AFL when he stayed silent due to the "fear of people thinking that I was gay or bisexual".

Brown will forever be etched into the game's history, but experts, advocacy groups and fans who have been pushing for systematic change say this is not a time for celebration.

Instead, they say it's an opportunity for self-reflection.

Praise for Mitch Brown after historic announcement Photo shows Mitchell Brown shouts at the crowd after a goal during a West Coast Eagles AFL game. Mitch Brown's historic announcement as the first publicly bisexual current or former male AFL player is met with support from across the sporting world.

"Our commitment is to keep making football an inclusive and welcoming environment for everyone to thrive," wrote AFL CEO Andrew Dillon in response to Brown's announcement.

But the AFL has not kept the sport an inclusive place and homophobia is its biggest issue, said Dr Erik Denison, a behavioural scientist at Monash University who has studied homophobia in the sport.

He said the AFL's issues surrounding homophobia were "deeply embedded".

" The AFL does not deny that it has a serious homophobic, behaviour and cultural problem. "

In 2014, the AFL signed a framework on national television to become a world leader in efforts to stop the pervasive homophobic language used at all levels of the game.

Then-AFL CEO Andrew Demetriou committed to eliminating homophobia in the sport in 2014. (AAP: Daniel Munoz)

Eleven years later, that same organisation spent three days deliberating the fate of Crows star Izak Rankine for using a homophobic slur against a Collingwood player.

The AFL entertained "compelling medical submissions" from Adelaide before handing Rankine a polarising four-week suspension that left the door slightly ajar for him to pull on the jersey this year if the Crows lost the qualifying final but made it to the grand final.

Rankine's ban pales in comparison to widespread impact of homophobia Photo shows Izak Rankine of the Crows prepares before a game. Young LGBTQIA+ Australians are turning away from community sport due to the high prevalence of homophobia, queerphobia and discrimination.

"We still have more work to do and we are committed to that," AFL general counsel Stephen Meade said following the ban.

But Dr Denison said he "couldn't really point to anything" the AFL had done to drive change in the 11 years since it committed to combat homophobia.

"I don't think it's time for the AFL community to be congratulating itself, sort of saying 'job done, here look at us, we finally have an openly gay bisexual player'," he said.

"This is time for the AFL community to really look in the mirror, listen to what Mitch Brown is saying, and do something about the problems that he's describing.

"This is an opportunity for the AFL to drive long-overdue change to culture and behaviour at all levels of the game."

'Homophobia permeates every square centimetre'

Rankine's slur was the sixth publicised incident of homophobia within the AFL in the past year-and-a-half.

Dr Denison said the problem lay within how normalised homophobic language had become, used as "day-to-day interactions" that he compared to "ritualistic bonding behaviour".

"Hyper masculinity and homophobia permeate every square centimetre," he said.

" It's just part of the furniture, part of the fabric, part of the wallpaper, part of everyday interactions in the sport. This is all they know. "

Collingwood defender Darcy Moore said the league has an ongoing issue with homophobia.

"Clearly, the amount of on-field incidents over the last few years shows we do still have an issue," he said.

Loading Instagram content

In the opening introduction to the AFL's inaugural LGBTQI+ action plan document released in 2024, CEO Andrew Dillon said, "the game of AFL has not always been a safe space for LGTBQI+ people".

Moore, who is the current AFL Players' Association president, said it's time to make "the game safer and more inclusive for everyone".

"We want to see action, we want to see policy change, we want to see systems thinking about shifting it, for sure."

Never a space to feel safe, even at local level

In an interview with The Daily Aus, Brown described the AFL's culture as "hyper-masculine".

"There was never once an opportunity to speak openly or explore your feelings or questions in a safe way," he said, adding that the weight of hiding his sexuality played a big part in his decision to retire at 28.

The former defender said the homophobia was pervasive and that one teammate said he would rather be in a cage full of lions than have to shower next to a gay man.

"There's been so many times in my life that I've seen things or heard things and not said anything, in fear of people thinking that I was gay or bisexual," he said.

Dr Denison said he "would expect the AFL to apologise to Mitch [Brown] for not creating a safe environment for him to play his sport".

"Mitch [Brown] was describing that he retired from the AFL, he says, because of wanting to escape this culture; he realised it was really unhealthy," he added.

And it doesn't just happen at a professional level.

Amateur football player Michael O'Donnell said the culture begins at a local level and was ever-present in the sport when he grew up before he came out.

Michael O’Donnell said in 2023 he hopes young gay players will have someone to look up to in the AFL. (Four Corners: Craig Hansen)

"Even as a 13-year-old, when I knew sort of who I was as a person, I looked around and thought, look, I'm not in a place that would accept me if I did come out," he said.

"It was a language, it was the way people spoke, not just around the football in a club culture, but in the crowds, in the media," Mr O'Donnell said, who currently plays for UNSW's Eastern Suburbs Bulldogs in Sydney.

" It's really hard to be what you can't see. "

Mr O'Donnell said that Brown's announcement was an "opportunity for reflection and education for so many people".

"It's not just a lesson for his teammates, hopefully it's a lesson for current AFL players, both of the local level and the professional level, to see the damage these sorts of comments can make."

Queer woman Sarah Pepper, who played football at various levels spanning almost a decade, said that local football clubs were a breeding ground for homophobia.

Loading...

"There is such a stereotype of what a male AFL player is expected to look like and act — and that is ingrained in the roots of local men's football," she said.

"You've got to work from local up, because that's where that toxic image develops in their minds.

"If you fix anything at its root, you fix the problem.

"All people should be able to play the sport and not feel like they can't because they don't fit the norm of what is currently expected in the male sporting world."

Dr Dennison agreed, claiming that players were "using this language to conform and belong and be part of the group".

"A player doesn't wake up in the morning and think, 'I'm going to use homophobic language today or sexist language'. They go into the club environment and they're often mimicking each other."

AFLW more inclusive and supportive

Unlike the AFL, a large percentage of players from the AFLW are part of the LGBTQIA+ community.

What society can learn from AFLW Pride Round Photo shows GettyImages-1763979293 The league's stars explain why Pride Round is so important, and why there is still a long way to go.

Former AFLW great and commentator Kate McCarthy said it was because the league was introduced after many of the players were already out and happy to identify as queer.

"I was happy with who I was as a person, and then I was playing AFLW," she told Triple M's Rush Hour with James Brayshaw and Billy Brownless.

"We had already come to that realisation ourselves, and weren't thrust into the spotlight and had to try and work out whether we told people or not: we just were."

A dedicated Pride Round was introduced in the AFLW in 2021. There is still yet to be a Pride Round introduced in the men's game.

Problems can't be fixed with just education modules

Dr Denison said as the behaviours were socially caused, "you need social solutions".

This season, the AFL launched a new LGBTQI+ education module that all players and officials were required to complete to combat homophobia.

ABC Grandstand commentator Corbin Middlemas said to his knowledge, a lot of players do not complete the module as intended.

"Speaking to some former players … a lot of the answers to those modules get shared in a WhatsApp group, essentially the players click through to the end, put in the answers and off they go," he said.

"Is that the best way forward?

" A place that's been a breeding ground for homophobia for 100 years is what we're basically trying to change here. "

Many in the AFL community say more education is required to tackle the issue of homophobia. (AAP: David Moir)

Players use harmful homophobic language to confirm and belong, Dr Denison said.

"That's why you can't fix these problems with education training modules or posters," he said.

"That has no effect on the social dynamics in the club environment that are causing these behaviours."

Brown's former West Coast Eagles coach Adam Simpson said that he had reflected this week on how he, the club and the league treat the issue of homophobia.

"You think you're going OK, but there's always improvement," he said, adding that everyone in the league should take time to reflect.

"That's why we've all evolved — it's generational as much as it's education."

The AFL and the AFL Players Association have been contacted for comments.

title: Want to buy pepper spray in NT? Here's what you need to know
text:
From Monday, September 1, Northern Territory residents can buy and use pepper spray or oleoresin capsicum (OC) spray for personal protection in a 12-month trial by the Northern Territory government.

This comes after escalating violent crime in the region.

Here's everything you need to know.

What is pepper spray?

Pepper spray, or oleoresin capsicum (OC) spray, is a non-lethal device used to incapacitate people by causing a painful burning sensation and temporary vision impairment.

For the trial, OC spray will be available in a canister and contain no more than 45 grams or 45 millilitres for a single-use spray.

Where can I buy pepper spray in the NT?

So far, the Northern Territory government has approved 11 NT firearms dealers to sell pepper spray for the trial.

Only some of these dealers have shop fronts.

To buy pepper spray from dealers who do not have shop fronts, you need to contact them directly.

Here is a list of approved dealers:

Dealer name Region Business phone THE GUN BOX Alice Springs 0438 502 260 EXODUS NOMINEES PTY LTD DEALERSHIP Darwin 0413 727 133 FISHING & OUTDOOR WORLD Darwin 08 8981 6398 EXMERE PTY LTD T/AS KATHERINE CAMPING & FISHING Katherine 08 8972 3456 ROD & RIFLE PTY LTD Katherine 08 8972 1020 COOLALINGA GUNS & AMMO PTY LTD Palmerston 08 8983 3166 GOLDFIELDS GUNS AND AMMO Tennant Creek 0428 361 577 GUN SUPPLIES (MUDKRAB P/L T/A) Alice Springs 0429 616 249 SSAA ALICE SPRINGS BRANCH DEALERSHIP Alice Springs 0427 525 183 SADADEEN FIREARMS (STEVAN STRAWBRIDGE T/AS) Sadadeen 0418 812 389 KKNIGHTSERVICE Casuarina 0409 462 094

Can I buy pepper spray online?

No, pepper spray can only be bought in person from a participating firearms dealer.

Who can buy pepper spray in the Northern Territory?

People, including visitors or tourists, who are 18 years or older in the Northern Territory can buy and use pepper spray if they present a valid photo ID.

Buyers will also need to complete a Buyer Declaration that they have no relevant criminal history, police, or court orders.

Buyers need to keep a copy of the declaration in their possession (physically or digitally) when carrying pepper spray. They will be required to present this to a police officer if asked, within one business day, or their spray may be seized.

What photo ID can I use to buy pepper spray?

You can use the original or a copy of:

an Australian passport or other passport containing an Australian visa that is in force

another document evidencing entitlement to Australian residency

a licence or permit issued under a law of the Commonwealth, or a State or Territory that specifies the person's date of birth

a proof of age card issued by a State or Territory

an NT Working with Children Clearance

Who can NOT buy pepper spray in the Northern Territory?

People who:

are not 18 years old

have been found guilty of an offence holding a maximum penalty of two or more years imprisonment unless: If you went to prison — at least five years have passed since you were released or since you were found guilty (whichever happened later); or If you did not go to prison — at least two years have passed since you were found guilty; or Otherwise — at least two years have passed since the day you were found guilty; or

have been found guilty of a disqualifying offence within the period of 10 years; or

are a reportable offender as defined in section 6 of the Child Protection (Offender Reporting and Registration) Act 2004 (NT); or

have a final or interim domestic violence order (DVO) currently in force against you, or a final DVO was in force within the last five years; or

have a personal violence restraining order or an interim personal violence restraining order is in force against you; or

are subject to an order, made in the NT or elsewhere, to keep the peace; or

have breached a condition of the Exemption: OC spray available here

People in the above list can not buy pepper spray in the Northern Territory.

If you are not sure whether you are prohibited from buying pepper spray, this document may help you.

How much will pepper spray cost?

The cost of the spray will likely vary, but a single can is expected to cost roughly $50.

NT is conducting a trial allowing the public to use pepper or "oleoresin capsicum" spray in self defence. (ABC News: Daryna Zadvirna)

How many cans of pepper spray can I buy at a time?

In public, you must not have more than two pepper spray cans, but there is no purchase limit on the number of cans people can buy.

This means that if you buy 10 cans of pepper spray, you need to make five separate trips to take your cans home.

If you are disposing of, surrendering or travelling to a place to dispose of or surrender your pepper spray, you are allowed to carry more than two cans.

How should I store my pepper spray and does it have a use by date?

You should store pepper spray in a cool, dry location in a safe place, away from children.

It is possible for pepper spray to explode under hot conditions, such as in a vehicle, so take care to store it appropriately.

Pepper sprays typically have a shelf life between two to four years from manufacture date, but always read the manufacturers product information on the can for advice pertaining to your specific spray.

Does my pepper spray need to be hidden?

Yes, pepper spray needs to be hidden from view when carried by a member of the public.

It will be an offence if the pepper spray is visible.

Crowd controllers and security officers are subject to different conditions regarding visible carrying of pepper spray.

WA is the only state in Australia where it is legal to carry pepper spray. (Adobe Stock: Dzmitry)

When can I use pepper spray?

You can use pepper spray in self-defence to:

defend yourself or another person

prevent or terminate the unlawful imprisonment of yourself or another person

protect property from unlawful appropriation, destruction, damage or interference

to prevent criminal trespass to any land or premises

to remove from any land or premises a person who is committing criminal trespass

Can I take pepper spray into other states or territories?

No. You may only carry pepper spray during the trial period in the Northern Territory.

If you travel interstate with pepper spray, you may be breaking the law. Always check the local laws before travelling.

Can I take pepper spray on planes and flights?

No, pepper spray is not allowed on planes or in flights, including domestic flights.

Pepper spray will cost about $50 a can. (ABC News: Daryna Zadvirna)

Do I need any training?

People are not required to do any training to use pepper spray, but it is encouraged that you read the directions for use on the label.

Could I hurt myself when using pepper spray on someone else?

Yes, if the pepper spray lands on you or you're in the vicinity of the spray it could also hurt you.

How can I give feedback on the pepper spray trial?

The Northern Territory government will open a survey for feedback on the trial from September 1 for members of the public to have their say on the trial.

The Community Reference Group (CRG) will also provide a forum for community feedback throughout the trial to guide any decisions around legislation.

Decision about the ongoing availability of pepper spray will be made at the end of the trial.

title: De Minaur holds his nerve to advance at US Open, with Kasatkina beaten by Osaka
text:
Alex de Minaur has surged into the US Open second week for a fifth time with a business-like win over wounded German Daniel Altmaier.

Australia's last player standing once more, de Minaur recovered from a set down to progress after Altmaier retired injured when di Minaur was leading 6-7 (9-7), 6-3, 6-4, 2-0 on Saturday (Sunday AEST).

Altmaier had battled for more than four hours and saved a match point in an epic third-round triumph over Stefanos Tsitsipas, after a five-set win over Hamad Medjedovic in the opening round.

He fought valiantly to back up and looked on track to cause a big upset when he took the first set in a tie-break after trailing three points to none.

Altmaier had his chances in the second set as well, but the energetic de Minaur was a man on a mission and pounced after his sapped opponent required two medical time-outs to treat a thigh strain.

Once down two sets to one, Altmaier looked a man resigned to defeat and Australia's eighth seed moved in for the kill.

A model of consistency, de Minaur has now made the last 16 at eight of the past nine grand slams.

The 26-year-old has a huge opportunity to make the Open quarterfinals for a third time when he faces Swiss qualifier Leandro Riedi, the world number 435, in the fourth round.

Riedi had beaten Argentine 19th seed Francisco Cerundolo in five sets in the opening round, and he was up against world number 76 Kamil Majchrzak when the Polish player retired at 5-3 down in the first set.

Osaka too strong for Kasatkina

Daria Kasatkina recovered from a first-set 'bagel' to force Naomi Osaka to three sets at the US Open before bowing out of the tournament. (Getty Images: Maddie Meyer)

Four-times major champion Naomi Osaka has powered to the US Open fourth round with a 6-0, 4-6, 6-3 win over Australian 15th seed Daria Kasatkina to continue her best grand slam run since 2021.

Osaka lit up Louis Armstrong Stadium in broad daylight, turning her third-round clash into a showcase of power and composure.

The Japanese player dominated early, absorbed a brief second-set wobble, and closed out the win to set up a blockbuster fourth-round showdown with American third seed Coco Gauff.

"Honestly, I was trying to tell myself to stay calm. I was so shaky today but I'm glad that it was an entertaining match," Osaka said.

"Whenever I come here it feels like home and you guys are very involved and I feel grateful. Thank you.

"Can someone come to the match and cheer for me?,.

"I mean it's kinda tough playing an American here but I hope you guys have adopted me. I kinda see her as a little sister so it's cool to be playing her here."

From the first point, Osaka looked sharp, putting pressure on Kasatkina with an early break gifted to her by a double fault before racing into a 3-0 lead.

Kasatkina's delivery deserted her in the first set with eight double faults and only 25 per cent of first serves landing as Osaka coolly dished out a bagel in 22 minutes.

Kasatkina, however, forced a decider after a scrappy second set riddled with breaks. Errors crept in on both sides, Osaka's frustration surfaced, and Kasatkina steadied enough to seize the lead.

Seven service breaks kept the set on edge before the Russian-born player finally held her nerve to level the match.

Osaka, however, regained her composure in the third.

She saved a break point with two blistering winners and surged into a 3-1 lead before closing out the match to stay on course for a third US Open title.

She will next play Gauff, who downed Polish player Magdalena Frech 6-3, 6-1 on Arthur Ashe Stadium.

AAP/Reuters/ABC

title: Grounds from your morning coffee are helping to reduce emissions
text:
As far as rubbish goes, it smells pretty good.

Former barista Ninna Larsen wheels a common rubbish bin forward, opens the lid and dumps a full load of coffee grounds.

Next to the pile of dark brown and black grounds is another, bigger mound, consisting of animal faeces, food waste and plant matter. This one smells less appealing.

Ms Larsen has another nine bins full of coffee grounds in the back of her van to be unloaded at Melbourne Zoo and sit right next to the zoo's organic waste dump.

"We have a partnership with around 400 cafes around Melbourne," she tells the ABC between loads.

"We collect around 1.2 tonnes of coffee per run and we have about two to three runs a day, so significant amounts of coffee a day."

Reground aims to transform coffee grounds into compost to help reduce greenhouse gas emissions. (ABC News: Iskhandar Razak)

Eleven years ago, Ms Larsen started Reground, a social enterprise that collects coffee waste to be reused.

She did it after finding out how much environmental harm Melbourne's love affair with lattes, long blacks and flat whites can cause.

"In landfill, coffee grounds emit a lot of toxic gases," she said.

The emissions include methane gas.

And Matt Genever, the CEO of Sustainability Victoria, said those emissions were a national problem — especially because Australia generated about 75,000 tonnes of ground coffee waste every year.

Reground's Ninna Larsen worked with Sustainability Victoria CEO Matt Genever to help turn the coffee grounds into compost. (ABC News: Iskhandar Razak )

But environmental groups have come up with an ingenious solution.

Sustainability Victoria has granted Reground more than $400,000 in recent years to help turn the grounds into compost, which doesn't emit harmful gases.

Coffee grounds on their own are too acidic to be used in a garden.

But if properly mixed with organic matter like animal waste, they can be highly effective fertilisers because they are high in potassium and nitrogen.

And one partner with an ample and never-ending supply of animal waste ready to be transformed is Zoos Victoria.

750 kilograms of animal waste

Melbourne Zoo has hundreds of animals creating waste every day.

Then there are food scraps from animals and visitors alike, as well as plant litter from dozens of gardens and enclosures.

"We produce about 1,000 tonnes a year of organic waste, Sarah Larkin from the zoo's sustainability team said.

"So that equates to 3,000 kilograms a day."

Of that, about 750 kilograms are daily animal waste.

Giraffes are contributing more waste to the compost program than any other animal at Melbourne Zoo. (Supplied: Zoos Victoria)

"The giraffes are the biggest contributors and now we have a new calf, we'll get even more from them," Ms Larkin said.

All of this organic waste is put through what's known as the "Hot Rot".

It is a 10-metre-long machine that mulches and churns organic waste into compost — including the coffee leftovers from Reground.

"Everything goes into it," Ms Larkin said.

"We have tigers and lions, so carcasses go into it. Bone is in there. Fruit from all of our animals. All sorts of organic rich material.

"It's already nutrient-dense.

"But it is a more nutrient-rich product with the coffee. And Reground drops off three-times a week."

Millions of kilograms of coffee grounds diverted

Once churned, the Hot Rot material comes out a very dark brown.

But despite the volume of excrement, once it is mixed and churned, the end product doesn't stink.

Instead, it has an earthy odour.

Melbourne Zoo is one of the zoos using the recycled compost in its gardens. (ABC News: Iskhandar Razak)

The zoo previously sold its compost to the public, but now only uses it on its own premises.

However, there are plans make it available to the community again soon.

Ms Larsen is quick to quote her enterprise's environmental impact.

title: Australia keeps pumping house prices, while Trump pursues 'state-run capitalism'
text:
Ben Picton, a senior macro strategist at Rabobank, had some interesting things to say last week.

In some notes to investors, he criticised Australia's housing policies, questioned the illusory nature of Australia's housing wealth, and critiqued the development model that Australia keeps pursuing.

He said the United States economy was also being re-made by the Trump administration at an "astonishing rate" and the commentariat was "clearly struggling to keep up".

He said traders needed to realise that the old playbook for global markets had disappeared.

The new paradigm of raw power politics

He made his argument in a couple of research notes (found here and here).

He began with the United States.

He said US President Donald Trump was now treating the US Federal Reserve similarly to the US Supreme Court, by seeking to stack the Fed with "ideological fellow travellers".

Ben Picton is a senior macro strategist from Rabobank Australia. (ABC News: Daniel Irvine)

He said it was further evidence that Trump's White House was dispensing with the "fiction" that central organs of government, like central banks, are politically neutral institutions:

"The unabashed politicisation of the supposedly independent and technocratic process of setting the price of money once again confirms that it is no longer the 1990s and that old ideas about optimal policy transmission, central bank credibility, and the need to insulate important decisions from the influence of the popular will offers little protection against the new paradigm of raw power politics. "Just as the interpretation of law is inherently political, the price of money is inherently political, and all aspects of national policy are being co-opted to support the MAGA vision of the United States and its place in the world."

He then shifted to Australia's housing market, questioning the nature of the "wealth" it is creating:

"The political nature of the price of money is, of course, a feature of other economies, too. "Down Under in Australia the Reserve Bank has recently cut rates for the third time — sparking another wave of [fear of missing out] buying in the country's already poisonously expensive housing market. "Tellingly, UBS's latest Global Wealth Report places Australia second only behind tax haven microstate Luxembourg in terms of the median household wealth. "By far the largest driver of Australia's household wealth is real estate, accounting for 53 per cent of the total compared to just 30 per cent in the United States. "The relative proportions of Australia's wealth composition versus [other countries] certainly raises questions about how much of that household wealth is illusory and liable to disappear when the housing market eventually reverts to fair value (as it always does)."

He then criticised the Albanese government's latest announcement to allow more first home buyers to purchase a property with a 5 per cent deposit.

A big dose of financialisation

Some quick background on this point.

On Monday last week, the Albanese government announced its decision to begin its expanded "Home Guarantee Scheme" earlier than planned.

It said its updated scheme would start on October 1, three months earlier than scheduled. (It had taken this policy to the federal election.)

Five per cent home deposit scheme to begin in October Photo shows A child scooters in front of a row of houses. A scheme to allow all first homebuyers to purchase a property with only a 5 per cent deposit will begin in October, three months earlier than Labor promised at the federal election.

Under the scheme already in place (introduced by the Morrison government in 2020), the federal government has been guaranteeing a portion of a first home buyer's home loan so they can purchase a home with a 5 per cent deposit and not pay lenders mortgage insurance.

But from October 1, the Albanese government will remove the cap on how many first home buyers can access the scheme each year, it will remove the income limit for applicants, and it will set a higher price cap for properties that can be purchased by applicants.

Treasury estimates an extra 20,000 guarantees will be issued in the first year of the expanded, uncapped scheme.

It says the scheme will also save young people between $87,000 and $350,000 in rent by drastically reducing the time it will take them to save a deposit and buy a home and get out of the private rental market.

See its modelling below:

On the ABC's News Daily podcast, Alan Kohler said that, by opening up the 5 per cent deposit scheme to all first home buyers, the Australian government was essentially taking over the lenders mortgage insurance industry (which the industry isn't happy about).

Loading...

And many economists have expressed frustration with the policy.

The independent economist Saul Eslake said he could understand why young people might like the expanded scheme, but it wasn't going to address the underlying problems with Australia's housing system.

Loading YouTube content

And Mr Picton joined the group of analysts criticising the scheme:

"Seemingly content to sacrifice their young to the Moloch of housing market speculation, the Australian government is continuing to do its best to ensure that fair value is never achieved and has … announced that they are 'helping' by bringing forward a scheme for the government to credit wrap first homebuyers with deposits as small as 5 per cent. "To put that another way, the taxpayer will be providing credit guarantees for buyers who are just 5 per cent away from negative equity in a generationally expensive market. "Concurrently, the ABC reports that thousands of houses purpose-built for the disabled on city fringes (where services for people with disabilities are thin on the ground) through the promise of turbocharged returns underwritten by a massive government honeypot for the investors who stumped up the capital are sitting empty — because not enough people with disabilities want to live there. "Totally not 2008 vibes at all. "This sort of silliness is common in Australia where there is apparently no problem that a big dose of financialisation can't 'fix' by creating new and bigger problems."

Trump is the director-in-chief of the US economy

He then tied all of the issues together.

He said there were clearly serious economic issues at play in Australia and the US:

"Australia's government [has] also committed to another round of cuts to 'nuisance' tariffs right at the time where the rest of the developed world is realising that – with the benefit of hindsight – such moves in the 1980s might have been a bad idea and the ability to make stuff in your own country is actually a very useful thing sometimes. "Contrast that thinking to what is happening in the USA, where Intel has apparently just agreed to allow the US government to take a 10 per cent stake in the company to ensure that strategically important semiconductor manufacturing occurs inside the United States and is treated as a national security priority. "Thinking from first principles, economics is the study of scarcity and it is the job of national governments to arrange the scarce factors of production (land, labour and capital) to best ensure the prosperity and security of their people. "Very clearly we are seeing two very different approaches to this problem of scarcity emerging. "Is the wealth of nations best employed to bid up the housing stock, making do-nothing speculators and ticket-clipping middlemen (real estate agents, mortgage brokers, banks etc) in the rentier economy fat? "Or is it better employed to ensure supremacy of real production and the dominance of strategic supply chains vis-à-vis potential adversaries?"

And he said investors needed to realise how much the world had changed.

He said the Financial Times was now describing Donald Trump as the Dirigiste-in-chief who has opened the door to state-run capitalism in the US.

"Which of course he is," he wrote.

Dirigism is a system in which the government uses far heavier hands to direct economic activity to fulfil the state's economic objectives, rather than being non-interventionist.

Vested interests and Australia's economy Photo shows Cascading rooftops in a brand new housing development in Alkimos, Western Australia. Australia is good at producing things, but it has excelled at producing vested interest groups that control key sectors of the economy.

"The Republican Party of Ronald Reagan is not the Republican Party of Donald Trump," he wrote.

"Friedmanite ideas of free markets and low touch government are out and a strong executive hand on the economic tiller is now very much in.

"For the first time in a long time the United States is back in the game of economic planning with a coherent (albeit risky) economic, industrial, financial … and military strategy now adopted to achieve foreign policy objectives.

"Many markets currently pricing for perfection – or for the assumed continuation of a single globalised system of prices – in the most imperfect of market conditions run the risk of being mugged sooner or later."

Then a few days later, on Friday, just to add to the chaos for investors, the US Court of Appeals ruled that most of Donald Trump's tariffs were illegal.

It said the tariffs could remain in place until October 14 to give the Trump administration time to file an appeal with the US Supreme Court.

In response, Trump claimed the ruling was "incorrect" and it had been made by a "highly partisan appeals court".

And he confidently predicted that, with help from the US Supreme Court (which has been stacked with judges by Republican presidents), the United States "will win in the end".

title: Sydney Marathon 2025 LIVE updates: Kiros, Hassan break Australian records
text:
Fan favourite, Eliud Kipchoge kept up with the leading group of men for most of the race

In the last 10km, he fell behind the core pack of runners and the two-time Olympic gold medallist, who has won 11 majors, finished in 10th place this morning.

Kipchoge thanks fans at the steps of the Opera House. Credit: Getty Images for adidas

“I’m happy to go across the finish line. I have nothing to prove,” Kipchoge said afterwards.

“My mission is to bring all the people together. Let us surpass 55,000 (from 35,000), actually, next year to run here. It’s a beautiful course. It’s a course whereby there is no other in this world.”

“It was not my day today...Above all, I have crossed the finish line to empower the people of Australia. To make Australia a running nation.”

title: Too much bass and not enough spectacle make this a shaky reinvention
text:
Some in the crowd are more easily convinced, however, with one fan continuously gushing that Cabello “knows what’s up” while sassily snapping their fingers. The energy in the arena only properly heats up once Cabello returns to the tracks most of her fans fell in love with her for – the upbeat Latin flare of Bam Bam and the sultry salsa-inspired sound of Havana. Here, the crowd heaves with excitement, everyone swaying their hips in almost perfect unison. Camila Cabello hasn’t performed in Australia since opening for Taylor Swift during the Reputation Tour. Credit: Richard Clifford It’s during these moments, when Cabello essentially has the crowd eating from her hand, that she herself appears to have the most fun. During the nu-disco pop track Quiet, she even implores the audience to go completely silent – a rare feat for an arena gig – before ramping their cheers up again at her own command. “I’ve stuffed my face with Tim Tams. I’ve even done a Tim Tam slam. I hope we return to Australia. We flew our butts all the way over here, and you’ve been the best crowd ever. You’ve been better than the best – you’ve been supersonic,” Cabello says, before seamlessly launching into I Luv It.

Cabello has said her new era is about embracing transformation and change. Yet, the best parts of her tour are when she reverts to the very sound that earned her multiple Grammy nominations back in 2019. Ultimately, Cabello has more sway than swagger, but perhaps we need to accept she’ll “never be the same” as before.

Reviewed by Nell Geraets JAZZ

Paul Grabowsky and Michelle Nicolle | Noir ★★★★★

Primrose Potter Salon, Melbourne Recital Centre, August 30 It’s hard to believe that Paul Grabowsky and Michelle Nicolle – both peerless artists and long-time luminaries of the Australian jazz scene – have never collaborated until now. Pianist Paul Grabowsky Credit: Alice Healy Yet Noir, their newly released album, marks their first musical outing together. Saturday’s concert (the first of two sold-out Melbourne shows) served as the official album launch, and the intimacy of the Recital Centre Salon made it the perfect setting for this repertoire.

As the title suggests, Noir luxuriates in darkness with songs of sadness and yearning, dashed dreams and broken hearts. Most of the songs are well-known, but stripped of their glossy patina to expose the honesty and fragility of the emotions they express. On stage, Nicolle exudes a natural warmth and positivity that bubbles up whenever she chats to the audience. But in this setting, as soon as Grabowsky’s hands touched the keys – setting the scene with quietly brooding introductions – Nicolle cloaked herself in the shadows of each song and its characters, making us believe these stories were her own. Jazz singer Michelle Nicolle. Credit: Giuseppe Dante Sapienza In classic film noir, the woman is often a femme fatale, her deceitful intent hidden under a seductive surface. Nicolle is the opposite, willing to unmask and reveal the inner workings of a tender heart. Her exquisite vibrato suggested a trembling vulnerability on Michel Legrand’s I Will Wait For You, as Grabowsky’s delicate accompaniment underlined the bittersweet beauty of the lyrics. Heartbreak Hotel – forever associated with Elvis’ sensual swagger – was reharmonised to accentuate the melancholy beneath the bluesy exterior, while I’m a Fool to Want You illuminated the darkness with flecks of light, courtesy of a Latin-tinged lilt and gently playful extemporisations on the melody.

Grabowsky’s own Rainbow Cake (co-written with Vince Jones) fitted perfectly into this repertoire with its mood of wistful nostalgia, as did Nicolle’s disarmingly poignant One Beer. Yes, it was an hour of sad songs, but these superb artists – who understand the value of sincerity and understatement – made it a pleasure to escape into the shadows.

Reviewed by Jessica Nicholas DANCE

Scenarios and Copy of the Copy ★★★★

Dancehouse, Carlton, until August 30 Both works currently showing at Dancehouse circle around problems of replication and imitation. These are enduring fascinations for choreographers but what makes this evening interesting is the contrast: one work meditates on sameness, while the other insists on difference. Scenarios is playful but also intimate. Credit: Takeshi Kondo

Scenarios, created and performed by Benjamin Hurley and Scott Elstermann, plays like a queer duet of self-fascination. Each performs as if the other were a mirror, a copy with no original, doubling gestures until resemblance tips into a kind of dreamy hallucination. Their shared identity is really a shared sensibility. A kind of rococo dandyism in duplicate. Movements are upright, measured and immaculately shaped. It’s disciplined dancing, with obsessively worked symmetries, synchronicities and long phrases that develop with tricky vocalisations. Copy of the Copy is interested in the way dance passes from body to body, teacher to pupil. Credit: Tiffany Garvie They cycle through many images or scenarios. A well-chosen text hints at the thrill of seeing yourself as another, while a darker vignette evokes the doppelgänger bent on self-annihilation. Yet the mood remains playful – even a little screwy – throughout these transformations. It’s cute but also intimate. In the end, the audience itself becomes a reflective medium, placed before the twins like one of the mirrors that organise the space, as if their doubled identities require us to be the final surface in which their resemblance is registered.

Priya Srinivasan, by contrast, in Copy of the Copy, is less concerned with uncanny reflections than with the way dance passes from body to body, teacher to pupil. In that transfer, copies are never exact: something is lost and something else is gained. Her work is resolutely theatrical, combining dance, video, audience interaction and even a little cooking. The registers are also multiple – comic, earnest, scholarly, confessional – and they continually shift. The effect is of a layered inquiry, staging transmission itself as a complex, unstable process. Loading Central to the performance is Srinivasan’s own dance lineage: her teachers and the teachers who taught them. As the work culminates, however, we get a more expansive mapping of connections, a deliberately overwhelming series of names stretching from the present to the late eighteenth century, crisscrossing continents, empires and colonies. As the names pile up, distinctions blur: which connections were fleeting encounters and which were nurtured over many years? Yes, we get a sense of the density of intercultural traffic, but the concept of the copy becomes a little vague and underdefined.
